University of Leicester https://www2.le.ac.uk These are the search results for the query, showing results 1 to 15. Canadian Recruitment Presentations \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd March 2015 https://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/law/news-events/law-news/canadian-recruitment-presentations The University of Leicester School of Law will be giving presentations in Canada during March 2015. The sessions will cover the University of Leicester, the School of Law, the city of Leicester, how to apply, scholarships, careers in Canada after completion of your Law degree, followed by question and answer session.
  • Toronto: Saturday 7 March, 1pm
    Room 1180, Bahen Centre for Information Technology, University of Toronto, 40 Saint George Street M5S 2E4
  • Hamilton: Sunday 8 March, 1pm
    Meeting Room, Visitors Inn, 649 Main St W, L8S 1A2
  • Toronto: Monday 9 March, 7pm
    Room 4279, Medical Sciences Building, University of Toronto, 1 King\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds College Cir, M5S 1A8
  • Ottawa: Tuesday 10 March, 7pm
    Room CO214, Residence Commons, Carleton University, 1125 Colonel By Dr, K1S 5B6
  • Halifax: Thursday 12 March, 7pm
    Room 2017, Marion McCain Arts and Social Sciences Building, Dalhousie University, 6299 South St, B3H 4R2
  • Montreal: Saturday 14 March, 1pm
    Room 110, Leacock Building, McGill University, 845 Sherbrooke O, H3A 0G4

    • All are welcome\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdthose considering an application and existing applicants along with guests. Prior-registration is not necessary.

    Details of how to apply can be found at www.le.ac.uk/canada-law

    Contact
    School of Law, University of Leicester, University Road, Leicester, UK, LE1 7RH
    tel: 011 44 116 252 5187 \ufffd\ufffd email: law@le.ac.uk

    ]]>     No publisher ab98 Law Event Canada News 2015-03-05T13:00:00Z News Item     \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe elusive nature of ICSID Tribunals\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Decisions\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd 18 March 2015 https://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/law/news-events/law-events/elusive-nature-of-icsid-tribunals Dr Paolo Vargiu (University of Leicester) This seminar addresses the issue of res judicata in investment arbitration. The concept of arbitral award in the ICSID Convention will be tested against the case-law to identify the nature and force of the decisions issued by ICSID tribunals during the course of the arbitral proceedings and not explicitly sanctioned by the ICSID Convention.

    This event is part of the 2014\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd2015 CELI seminar series.

    Details

    Open to: Staff, students, graduates and members of the public.

    Date: Wednesday 18 March 2015, 1.30 - 3 pm

    Venue: Room FJ164, School of Law, Fielding Johnson Building, University of Leicester

    Contact: For more information please contact Dr Albert Sanchez Graells at a.sanchez-graells@le.ac.uk or the School of Law Reception at 0116 252 2363.

    Poster: The elusive nature of ICSID Tribunals\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Decisions (PDF)

    ]]>     No publisher ab98 Event Centre for European Law and Internationalisation (CELI) Law 2015-03-05T12:50:00Z News Item     Legal Week 2014\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd2015 https://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/law/news-events/law-events/legal-week-201420132015 A discussion group for those interested in Law and the legal implications of current events. Next event: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdPirates, trolls and biopatents \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Are intellectual property rights outdated?\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd

    Hosted by Dr Sebastian Peyer and Dr Paolo Vargiu.

    Tuesday, 10 March 2015, 5.00\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd6.00pm, Jan Grodecki Room, Fielding Johnson Building

    After a successful first year, the School of Law is again launching \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdLegal Week\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd.

    This is an informal discussion group for students and staff interested in Law (although not necessarily studying or researching it) and a curiosity for the legal implications of current events.

    The format is based on a discussion of current issues with the goal of helping participants gain a better understanding of the applicable legal frameworks. Such events include

    • \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdPirates, trolls and biopatents \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Are intellectual property rights outdated?\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, Tuesday, 10 March 2015.
    • Greek bailout discussions, Tuesday, 24 February 2015.
    • \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdOil prices, the OPEC and the stability of the Eurozone\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, Tuesday, 10 February 2015.
    • \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdFreedom of expression in light of the Charlie Hebdo terrorist attacks\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Tuesday, 27 January 2015
    • \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe Assisted Dying Bill after its discussion at Committee stage in the House of Lords\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd (link), Tuesday, 18 November 2014.
    • \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe Pistorius Trial: What can we learn from it?\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, Tuesday, 4 November 2014.
    • The devolution process started after the Scottish referendum.
    • The power to medically treat patients without their consent.
    • The so called Google right to be forgotten
    • The implications of international embargoes following use of force

    Legal week is particularly valuable is for students wanting to develop analytical skills, commercial awareness and oral expression.

    For more information, please feel free to email Dr Albert Sanchez-Graells (a.sanchez-graells@le.ac.uk).

    Legal week poster (PDF)

    ]]>     No publisher ab98 News Law Event 2015-03-05T10:20:00Z News Item     Guest lecture: Reflections: From Law School to Attorney General \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Tuesday 24 February, 2015 https://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/law/news-events/law-events/guest-lecture-minister-mackay-minister-of-justice-and-attorney-general-of-canada-24-february-2015 Guest Lecture: The Honourable Peter Gordon MacKay, MP for Central Nova, Nova Scotia Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada. The Canadian Attorney General and Minister of Justice, Minister MacKay, will be speaking about his role as a lawyer: from\ufffd\ufffdhis time as a law student, to prosecutor, to becoming the Attorney General and Minister of Justice, as well as other opportunities that emerge from the field of law.

    In July 2013, Mr. MacKay was appointed Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada. Previously, he was appointed Minister of Foreign Affairs and Minister of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency in February 2006 and Minister of National Defence in August 2007.

    Before entering politics, Mr. MacKay had a private law practice in New Glasgow, specializing in criminal and family law. In 1993, he accepted an appointment as Crown Attorney for the Central Region of Nova Scotia. He prosecuted cases at all levels, including youth and provincial courts as well as the Supreme Court of Canada.

    Details

    Open to: open to students and staff

    Date: Tuesday 24 February 2015, 4pm

    Venue: Peter Williams Lecture Theatre

    Contact: Dr Gemma Turton, t: 0116 252 2395 e: gemma.turton@le.ac.uk

    Event poster

    ]]>     No publisher ab98 Event Law Canada 2015-02-23T14:40:00Z News Item     \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdTowards Marriage Equality: Reflections from Scholar-Activists\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd https://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/law/news-events/law-events/towards-marriage-equality-reflections-from-scholar-activists Leicester graduate Professor Sue Wilkinson speaks of her legal case, Wilkinson v Kitzinger (2007), and the Marriage Same Sex Couples Act 2013. On Wednesday 18 February, Leicester graduate Professor Sue Wilkinson visited the School of Law to give a talk to LLB students entitled \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdTowards Marriage Equality: Reflections from Scholar-Activist.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd The focus of Professor Wilkinson\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds talk was the legal case brought to the English High Court reported as Wilkinson v Kitzinger [2007] FLR 195, for the recognition of her marriage to Professor Celia Kitzinger in 2003.

    This case raised an issue of the conflict of laws; both parties had their home (domicile) in England and in 2003 validly married in the Canadian State of British Columbia. Were they \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdmarried\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd in the eyes of English law? Under English law their relationship was deemed a \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdCivil Partnership\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd (Civil Partnership Act 2004, s.215). In this case, Professor Wilkinson petitioned the court to have the parties\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd same sex marriage recognised in England as a marriage. The court was required to consider the compatibility of English law, under the Civil Partnership Act 2004, with Articles 8, 12 and 14 of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR).

    This case is of interest not just to law students interested in the discrete legal question as to how English law defines foreign relationships and the criteria for their recognition in England, but also to social science students interested in wider issues of how equality and social justice, regardless of gender, can be assured and adequately reflect the construction of \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdfamily\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and personal relationships in the twenty-first century. The talk provided an overview of the wider historical context of equality for personal relationships in various countries such as the United States and Canada and the steps towards equality under English law via the Civil Partnership Act 2004 and the Same Sex Marriage Act 2013. The talk also provided a first-hand insight into the Professors\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd experience of what it was like to engage with the litigation process in the English High Court at that time and their own subsequent campaign towards equal marriage rights. On 13 March 2014, Professor Wilkinson and Kitzinger\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds marriage was recognised as a marriage by the introduction of the Marriage Same Sex Couples Act 2013 in England and Wales. The talk concluded with further reflections on how the 2013 Act is another \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdstep\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd towards full equality for all personal relationships.

    Details

    Contact: lorna.e.gillies@le.ac.uk

    Event poster

    ]]>     No publisher ab98 Conflicts of Law Law Event Civil Justice Family Law Human Rights News 2015-02-23T13:55:00Z News Item     Postgraduate Fair for Current Students \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Wednesday 25 February 2015 https://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/law/news-events/law-events/postgraduate-fair-for-current-students-2013-wednesday-25-february-2015 1:00pm\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd3:00pm in the ARC, Students\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Union. Find out more about studying as a postgraduate at Leicester, including how you may be able to receive a 50% reduction in your course fee. You will be able to speak to staff and postgraduate students from our departments, to chat about our Masters courses and also find out about your funding options.

    Postgraduate Fair for Current Students

    ]]>     No publisher ab98 Law Scholarships LLM Event 2015-02-20T15:53:35Z News Item     New edition of leading book on Public Procurement in the EU https://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/law/news-events/law-news/new-edition-of-leading-book-on-public-procurement-in-the-eu Dr Albert Sanchez-Graells\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd second edition of \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdPublic Procurement and the EU Competition Rules\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd in press with Hart Publishing (Oxford). After having been shortlisted for the 2012 Prix Vogel in Economic Law, the first edition of this work has been established as the most comprehensive attempt to date to explain the many ways in which EU public procurement law and EU competition law interact and overlap in the creation of the EU\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds internal market. This convergence between competition and public procurement law is particularly apparent in the 2014 Directives on public procurement, which consolidate the principle of competition in terms very close to those advanced by Dr Sanchez-Graells in the first edition. This second edition deepens the analysis of the market behaviour of the public buyer from a competition perspective and aims to continue influencing developments of EU public procurement law.

    Dr Sanchez-Graells is a leading expert in EU public procurement and competition law matters. He is currently a member of the European Court of Auditors expert panel on EU institutions procurement. He has invited to speak at over 20 international conferences on the topic and his coming speaking engagements include the universities of Oxford, Cambridge, Nottingham, Lisbon, Porto and Barcelona. His up to date commentary of EU public procurement law can be followed in his blog: http://howtocrackanut.blogspot.co.uk/.

    ]]>     No publisher ab98 News EU Law Law Publish 2015-02-20T15:33:20Z News Item     Law School SSRN e-Journal 2015 issue 1 https://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/law/news-events/law-news/law-school-ssrn-e-journal-2015-issue-1 The first issue of 2015 in the School\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds SSRN e-Journal series has been distributed. It showcases research by several members of staff and features collaborative outputs from the international network of the School of Law. This issues features papers from Dr Jule Mulder, on comparing European harmonised law; Dr Albert Sanchez-Graells, who writes about the qualification, selection and exclusion of economic operators under Spanish public procurement law and, together with Ignacio Herrera Anchustegui (University of Bergen), on the impact of public procurement aggregation on competition; Prof Jos\ufffd\ufffd Miola, on the issue of the separation of the institutional, personal and professional ethical standards involved in interactions between doctor and patient; Dr Horace Yeung, on the path of development of the two leading commercial centres in China amidst the wider context of Chinese economic reform; and Prof Katja Ziegler, on the relationship between international law and EU law.

    All papers are also available at the free-access the University of Leicester Law School Research Papers Series Repository, which forms part of the SSRN Legal Scholarship Network. The Repository also contains a range of other published and working papers by members of the School.

    Papers in the Leicester Series can be viewed at: http://www.ssrn.com/link/U-Leicester-LEG.html

    To subscribe to the Leicester e-Journal go to: http://hq.ssrn.com/jourInvite.cfm?link=U-Leicester-LEG

    ]]>     No publisher ab98 Event Centre for European Law and Internationalisation (CELI) Commercial and Corporate Law Law 2015-02-02T15:05:00Z News Item     Midlands Postgraduate Conference in Law \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd 8 May 2015 https://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/law/news-events/law-events/midlands-postgraduate-conference-law-2015 This conference will enable students at the different universities across the Midlands (and beyond) to meet and share their work. The event runs from Friday 8 May and Saturday 9 May 2015 under the theme Law: Rhetoric and Reality. The broad theme of the Conference is: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdLaw: Rhetoric and Reality\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd. We aim to contrast the rhetoric behind the law with its content, and to discuss its operation (\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdlaw in action\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd) and effects. The conference will be general in nature but with sections dedicated to specific areas of law.

    The deadline for submitting abstracts is Monday 9 February 2015.

    We aim to finalise the programme and abstracts commencing 13 February 2015.

    Participating Law Schools: University of Birmingham, Birmingham City University, De Montfort University, University of Leicester, University of Nottingham, and Nottingham Trent University.

    Law: Rhetoric and Reality conference

    ]]>     No publisher ab98 Event Conference Postgraduate Law 2015-01-19T15:30:00Z News Item     Law, Rhetoric and Reality? https://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/law/news-events/law-rhetoric-reality/law-rhetoric-and-reality A two-day postgraduate conference to discuss and exchange on \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdLaw, Rhetoric and Reality\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd.

    Midlands Postgraduate Law Conference

    8\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd9 May 2015

    Overview

    The law impacts on many aspects of our daily lives, but it has been well established that the \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdlaw in books\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd differs from the \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdlaw in action\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd (McBarnet, 1978, 1981, 2004) as the law often fails to live up to its rhetoric. The \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdlaw in books\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd is open to interpretation and challenge. Local, national and global developments often require that the law adapt. On occasions the law remains stagnant and the exercise of discretion often results in the law being applied in varying ways. The impact is such that the law can be experienced in many different ways. To understand the full force of the law we must query both the rhetoric and the reality.

    As \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdresearchers in training\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd we should synthesise, discuss and challenge the law. The Midlands Postgraduate Law Conference aims to provide a forum to share these ideas and perspectives under the theme \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdLaw, Rhetoric and Reality\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd.

    Details

    Call for papers: Midlands Postgraduate Conference in Law 2015 Call for papers ( PDF) 9 February, 2015 deadline.

    Date: 8-9 May 2015

    Venue: University of Leicester Main Campus (Maps and directions)

    Contact: For more information please contact Dr. Maribel Canto Lopez, micl1@le.ac.uk

    Administrative enquiries: Contact Teresa Rowe, teresa.rowe@le.ac.uk

    Schedule

    Friday 8 May
    9.00 Registration
    9.30 Presentations
    (TBA)
    12.30 Lunch
    13.30 Presentations
    (TBA)
    16.30 Day one close
    Saturday 9 May
    9.30 Presentations
    (TBA)
    12.30 Lunch
    13.30 Presentations
    (TBA)
    16.30 Day two close
    ]]>     No publisher ab98 Event Law Postgraduate Conference 2015-01-09T14:50:00Z Page     University of Leicester Canadian Law Intervarsity Mooting Competition https://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/law/news-events/university-of-leicester-canadian-law-intervarsity-mooting-competition/university-of-leicester-canadian-law-intervarsity-mooting-competition The inaugural competition will begin in early February 2015, taking place over 3 rounds and concluding with a final at Canada House in March 2015. Competition rules (PDF)

    Institutions can enter the competition by emailing the competition convenor, Dr Tracey Elliott by the 19 January, informing her of your intention to enter the competition and providing staff and student contact details. An entry fee of \ufffd\ufffd20 must also be paid using the shop@le website by the 30 January 2015.

    The competition moot is now available and may be obtained by emailing Dr Tracey Elliott, who is happy to answer any queries in relation to the competition. For students who are unfamiliar with researching the law in this field and who are unfamiliar with drafting factums, the following websites are likely to be of assistance:

    CANLII: This site aims to make Canadian law accessible for free vis the internet.

    Supreme Court of Canada website

    How to prepare a factum for the Court of Appeal (PDF) from the Ontario Justice Education Network

    ]]>     No publisher ab98 Event Law Canada Mooting Competition 2015-01-05T16:30:00Z Page     Law School rises in research rankings https://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/law/news-events/law-news/law-school-rise-in-research-rankings Excellent research output increases Law school rank by 12 places. The School of Law has shot up 12 places in the recent REF rankings compared to the 2008 RAE, as measured by overall results based on a combination of output quality, research environment and social impact. It is 11th in terms of Research Power and in the top 20 as measured by the quality of its publications (outputs). 77.9% of the School\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds publications was graded as world-leading or internationally excellent in terms of originality, significance and rigour.

    ]]>     No publisher ab98 Research News Law 2014-12-18T11:05:00Z News Item     Law professor quoted by government and national press on the Medical Innovation Bill https://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/law/news-events/law-news/law-professor-quoted-by-governement-and-national-press-on-the-medical-innovation-bill Professor Jos\ufffd\ufffd Miola's expertise and work on the issues surrounding Lord Saatchi's Medical Innovation Bill has been used the by the UK Government and high profile media outlets. He was quoted by the government's response to the Department of Health's consultation paper, and his work in connection with the bill has been used by\ufffd\ufffdThe Times newspaper, The Guardian newspaper,\ufffd\ufffdDeutsch Welle radio and briefings provided by Cancer Research UK amongst others.

    He also presented 'Conversation on the Medical Innovation Bill' to University of Leicester staff and students with Professor Dean Fennell from the Department of Cancer Studies.

    ]]>     No publisher ab98 Medical law Law News 2014-12-12T15:10:00Z News Item
